p.s: You can easily cut the sequence into 3 parts.
1: the dinner
2: King and Mav arguing
3: the police
In the first scene theresthere are quick changes between the settings.
There's much talking from all sides of the family, everytime someone talks, a close-up of their face is shown.
It's easy to tell the director wanted to show the emotions of the characters with that.
After Chris giving the interview they're all happy and relieved.
In their prayer it's all together, the faces with expressions and the dialogdialogue with the thoughts.
In the part with King the director wanted to do a slow change from the happy family feeling to the feeling of being in danger.
That's shown by the dramatic position of King and his gangsters.
They're standing directly in front of the window, standing still and starring through the window.
When Starr first sees them, you see them from the point of her view with a little zoom.
While all this happens the sounds of the diner and the rest of the family get muffled.
All this creates a dark atmosphere that makes you feel the danger that Starr (and later Mav) get to feel.
The lights outside the diner are also more dark than bright, what supports the feeling of danger and not being safe.
The scene with the police is the most dynamic.
It has a steady growing tension.
When the police gets out of the car Mav tries to back ofoff to the door of the diner.
They catch up and press him against the wall.
For the whole scene the red and blue light of the police car refelcts on the nearby buildings, persons and objects.
This gives the watcher the regular tension of the police presensepresence.
Also the short camera settings in scenes with much movement like Mav being pushed on the ground etc. are more settings per second.
You for example see Seven making a quick move back as the cop tries to touch him, Mav being pushed down and Mav's face.
It helps to build up tension.
In the scene where the cop realises, Starr is the witness you see his face for a long time before he speaks his thought.
The director used that to make the watcher think himself, what the policeman is thinking and what he'll do after realizing.
This gives everything a special kind of tension.
To sum up it's easy to see that the director used many devices for one purpose; building up tension.
He uses light, movement, perspectives and even the watcherswatcher's own mind to do it.
As for violence (that is more shown indirectly than directly in this scene) the director used quick camera jumps and fast movement in the scene.
